channel.title: NPR Morning Edition
channel.description: Morning Edition takes listeners around the country and the world with multi-faceted stories and commentaries every weekday. Hosts Steve Inskeep, Leila Fadel, Michel Martin and A Mart√≠nez bring you the latest breaking news and features to prepare you for the day.

item.title: The world waits as cardinals work to choose the next pope
item.description: The world is watching the Vatican on Thursday as 133 cardinals work to choose which of them will be the next pope.

item.title: Not taking India-Pakistan escalation seriously a 'huge risk,' warns conflict expert
item.description: Efforts to mediate the India-Pakistan conflict are not going to work "unless the U.S. steps in with full sincerity," Praveen Donthi, a senior analyst with the International Crisis Group, told NPR.

item.title: The latest on the escalating conflict between India and Pakistan
item.description: Pakistan shot down Indian drones on Thursday that were flying over major cities, Pakistan's military spokesman said. This comes after India launched multiple strikes across Pakistan on Tuesday.

item.title: Morning news brief
item.description: Hear the latest on the escalating conflict between India and Pakistan, Trump administration wants to send migrants to Libya, Federal Reserve policymakers hold interest rates steady for now.

item.title: A music executive says women forced to pick 'survival' over consent in music industry
item.description: Music executive Ty Stiklorius recounts her personal experiences within the music industry ahead of opening statements in Sean Combs' trial, which are scheduled for May 12.

item.title: City councils in Boise and Salt Lake City work around restrictions on LGBTQ+ flags
item.description: City councils in Boise and Salt Lake City have added LGBTQ+ pride flags to the banners that can be flown on city properties, working around new state laws that restrict which flags can be displayed.

item.title: How Europe is commemorating the 80th anniversary of the Nazis' surrender in WWII
item.description: Thursday marks 80 years since Victory in Europe Day, when the Allies accepted Nazi Germany's unconditional surrender. The day will be marked with memorials and moments of silence across Europe.

item.title: Hollywood industry employees leaving jobs to become independent content creators
item.description: Writers, producers and other creatives are leaving their Hollywood jobs to become content creators. NPR's A Martinez speaks with Amy Suto, who quit Hollywood to create content independently.

item.title: Trump administration plans to deport migrants to Libya and other countries
item.description: The Trump administration wants to send migrants to Libya, possibly as soon as this week. U.S. officials have been negotiating with other countries willing to take in people deported from the U.S.

item.title: Documentary IDs Israeli soldier who allegedly killed journalist Shireen Abu Akleh
item.description: NPR talks with filmmaker Dion Nissenbaum about the documentary "Who Killed Shireen?" In it, the Israeli soldier who allegedly killed Palestinian American journalist Shireen Abu Akleh is identified.
